title: bug: hacking static folders
body: Prevents use of absolute paths or a path that walk up in the directory tree for static folders

title: fix: actix integration with state
body: The actix integration was not compatible with shared state (PgPool does not implement copy), so I removed the Copy bound. Added example in https://github.com/shuttle-hq/examples/pull/8

title: feat: create `init` project from correct dir
body: When using `init` to bootstrap a project, at the end a user is prompted to create their project container. The path to load the project from is the `ProjectArgs` working directory, which would be different from the the path to the directory the user created via `init` (unless working dir was default `.` and user selected default `.` for project dir). In most cases this would result in an error: "could not locate the root of a cargo project".

title: feat: build tests in release profile, limit build workers
body:
This limits the workers used by `cargo build` to 8 for deployments, reducing memory usage during deployments while still keeping build times low. 

It also set tests that are ran after building a project for deployment to build in the release profile, this means that this step doesn't have to recompile the crates in the debug profile for testing.

title: refactor: switch away from cargo package
feat: implement workspace inheritance
body: This implements the new workspace inheritance feature from 1.64. For this PR I elected to just add some external crates to the workspace dependencies, since `cargo-chef` does not support local crate workspace deps yet. When it does, we can add more. I'm happy to add more external deps to this PR, but it should also be easy to do as part of other PRs as we see commonly used deps that aren't inherited.

title: feat: bump pinned rust version to 1.65
body: Due to the error in CI on the first commit of this PR (`E: Unable to locate package protobuf-compiler`), I ended up backporting the updated protoc install command from shuttle-next.

title: Add spinner wait for `project new` and `project status --follow`
body:
- feat: Wait env ready after `project new`
- feat: Add --follow argument to `project status` command
- refactor: Remove unused reference
- refactor: Unify in same function the code for wait with spinner

This PR closes #492

title: Doc: Fix command to prime database with docker-compose
body: Signed-off-by: Federico Guerinoni <guerinoni.federico@gmail.com>

title: feat: static file support for a single folder
Doc: Improve contributing documentation
body:
In the doc it mentions to go to subfolder of examples but it was not
there :).

Signed-off-by: Federico Guerinoni <guerinoni.federico@gmail.com>

title: feat: interactive project initialization
body:
PR for #493.

All the functionality should be there. However, when it came to writing tests, I noticed that the current integration test setup can't really test stdin/stdout. I think we'd have to call it as a standalone program to do so. Does anyone have any thoughts on that? ~I'm happy to try and change it to such a setup tomorrow.~ Edit: I've added some tests with that sort of setup now.

cc @oddgrd @brokad

title: feat: bump rust to 1.64, bump dependencies
body:
Bump the pinned rust version of containers to 1.64, and update dependencies. I wasn't able to bump `cargo` from 0.64 to 0.66, as it has some conflict over libgit2-sys with `cargo-edit`. I bumped everything else, most of it did not require code changes, except for configuring the timeout for the aws sdk in provisioner and general axum changes. These code changes are in separate commits.

I did not upgrade clap to 0.4 in provisioner, deployer and cargo-shuttle, this might be better to do in a separate PR.

This branch is set to use the updated examples from this branch: https://github.com/shuttle-hq/examples/pull/4, since quite a few of the frameworks will have incompatible version with the current ones in examples `main`. 

Another thing to note is that this PR upgrades our pinned tokio to 1.22, which works with all the updated frameworks. This, and updating the framework versions, means users will be forced to upgrade as well. 

Note: ~I'm not sure why the latest CI run segfaulted, it seems to only use tokio 1.22 and it passes locally.~ Edit: after ignoring the actix test (which is missing an example currently), the CI fails in a normal fashion.

Closes #425

title: Feat: parse shuttle::endpoint macro
body:
Create a functional macro in codegen that parses the entire codeblock of the macro and strips out every `#[shuttle::endpoint]` annotation, parsing them into `Endpoint`s that can be turned into axum routes.

I might think of a few more tests to add tomorrow, but this should be ready for review.

Thanks @chesedo for guiding me through this one!

body: This is the first half of the codegen for our new framework. It just generates the same code that was created by hand for the axum wasi implementation

title: feat: restore removed containers

This
- Expands the default subnet to `/16`
- Has gateway re-create containers that have disappeared if they used to be ready, keeping the same image and fqdn as before

title: ci: green
body: The CI is a bit slow to build the test crates, so giving it a bit more time

title: Feat(shuttle-next): stop runtime services
body:
Add a stop method to `runtime.proto`. We can't currently stop services on the legacy runtime, since we can't actually drop the legacy runtime. I implemented a stop method for it before discovering it was not possible, I left it there but with a comment. I'm happy to replace it with a `todo!()` if that's more tidy for now. 

I implemented stop for wasm serenity and axum, which is tested (manually) and works. We may want to setup integration tests for these runtimes with some helpers for the grpc requests, but maybe in a separate PR?

I opted for `oneshot` channels that are set on each `start`, but on second thought it may have been a mistake. I suppose the runtime should be able to load -> start several services, keeping them all alive until their ID/name receives a stop request. Meaning `broadcast` channels may be the correct choice here.

Note: This PR also changes the Dockerfile to install a newer protoc binary directly, rather than with `apt`, to allow us to use explicit optional fields in the protobufs. This is also done for the CI.

title: bug: deployer freezes
body:
Reduce freezes in deployer by spawning less. This reduces complete lockups by deployer and makes deployer responsive to API calls during build jobs

Closes ENG-274

body: I noticed there were a few broken example Links in the Readme and took the liberty to fix them

title: feat: verify project exists before sending destroy task
body: This is a quick fix to the issue of `cargo project rm` always returning `destroying`. Draft while I look into improving cli feedback.

title: feat: add a custom domains admin route
[WIP] feat(shuttle-next): POC of axum wasm router
body: This is an experimental PR to test out ways to interact with an axum wasm app. A hyper server is started in the runtime on load -> start request, that serves a wasm axum router linked to the runtime with WASI. Request parts are serialized as rmp and passed through along with the body (slice of bytes) to the router as file descriptors, and vice versa.

WIP feat: count recent start events before restart
body:
Count recent start events before restarting a stopped container, to prevent it from looping restarts indefinitely.

I tested that it does indeed not attempt to start if it has started 3 times in the last 15 minutes.

title: misc: add more helpful flags to Makefile
body:
And do not run "images" target when targeting "up". 

On my end, this still triggers a build of the images initially, unless when `DOCKER_COMPOSE_FLAGS=--no-build` is set, which matches the [documented behavior](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/compose_up/#description). Contributing guidelines also make it clear you want to run `make images` first in order to sync up images with their most recent versions, and the CircleCI workflows that do `make up` and `make test` also run `make images` prior. So this should not require changing anything else.

title: refactor: provide better context for errors

refactor: do our own health checks on deployer containers
body:
We are doing this because the docker health checks eat up 25% of a single CPU core and we are spinning up many of these containers.

Open issue: https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/39102
Other reports: https://www.reddit.com/r/docker/comments/b68r53/healtchecks_add_high_cpu_load/

title: Feat/update contributing
body:
Update the contribution guide. 

When doing this, I noticed we don't do any clean up after e2e tests. This is fine for CI, but locally we will have conflicts for the admin user (name PK, key UNIQUE) as well as conflicts for the projects (a project with that name already exists). There will also currently be ~10 running deployers running after the tests complete, which won't be cleaned up with `make down`. 

To remedy this I did:
1. ~~If the admin username already exists, just update the key. This is a quick fix with a caveat: if a super-user is created with a different username but a non-unique key, the tests will fail. But if the tests are run without modifying the setup code, this shouldn't be a problem.~~ Remove `ensure_success` from the superuser creation in test setup.
2. Implement `Drop` for `helpers::Services`: when the test completes `project rm` will be called, and this should occur even if the test fails.

feat(deployer): implement container memory limits
body: Impose memory limits on deployer containers. The hard limit is set at 6GiB, but if low memory is detected on the host a 4GiB limit will be applied. If a container hits the limit it will be killed (signal: 9, SIGKILL).
